message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has prostate cancer with aggressive features and multiple metastatic sites. Radical prostatectomy will not be effective at this late stage. Active surveillance is only appropriate for low-risk prostate cancer. Chemotherapy may be an option, but androgen deprivation therapy is the most appropriate next step in management as it aims to reduce the level of testosterone, which can slow down the tumor growth and relieve the bone pain.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms and test results indicate prostate cancer with aggressive histologic features and metastases. Androgen deprivation therapy is the most appropriate next step in management for advanced prostate cancer. Active surveillance is appropriate for low-risk prostate cancer, while chemotherapy and radical prostatectomy are not initial treatment options for advanced prostate cancer.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has prostate cancer with aggressive histologic features and multiple metastatic sites. Active surveillance and radical prostatectomy are not appropriate at this stage. Chemotherapy may be considered, but Androgen deprivation therapy is the initial recommended treatment for metastatic prostate cancer to suppress the growth of the tumor. The high PSA level and testosterone within normal range suggested that the cancer is hormone-sensitive.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has advanced prostate cancer with bone metastasis and aggressive histologic features, indicating a poor prognosis. Androgen deprivation therapy (ADT) is the most appropriate next step in management to slow the progression of the cancer. Surgery (radical prostatectomy) and chemotherapy are typically reserved for earlier stages of prostate cancer. Active surveillance is not appropriate for a patient with aggressive prostate cancer with metastasis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and high PSA level indicate prostate cancer with metastasis. Androgen deprivation therapy is the recommended treatment for advanced prostate cancer. Active surveillance is not recommended at this stage, and chemotherapy or radical prostatectomy may provide little benefit.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, laboratory results, and imaging studies suggest that the prostate cancer has already metastasized. Active surveillance and radical prostatectomy are not appropriate options for this patient. Chemotherapy may be an option for metastatic prostate cancer, but androgen deprivation therapy is the standard treatment. The patient’s prostate cancer is likely dependent on testosterone, so reducing the amount of testosterone in the body may help slow down the growth of the cancer.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s prostate-specific antigen is elevated, the DRE showed a hard nodule, and the biopsy confirmed prostate cancer with aggressive features, and metastasis has been detected on the radionuclide bone scan. Androgen deprivation therapy is the most appropriate next step in management for advanced prostate cancer. Active surveillance is only appropriate for low-risk patients, while chemotherapy is not the standard first-line treatment for advanced prostate cancer. Radical prostatectomy may not be appropriate for this patient given the extent of the disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s PSA level, DRE findings, and biopsy results suggest prostate cancer with aggressive histologic features. The bone scan shows multiple metastatic sites, indicating advanced disease. Androgen deprivation therapy is appropriate in this case, as it is a standard of care for metastatic prostate cancer. Active surveillance would not be appropriate given the aggressive nature of the disease, and chemotherapy and radical prostatectomy alone are not effective for metastatic prostate cancer.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Prostate cancer with metastatic spread requires systemic treatment, and androgen deprivation therapy is the preferred approach. Active surveillance is not appropriate for this advanced stage of prostate cancer. Chemotherapy may be used in combination with androgen deprivation therapy but is not a primary treatment. Radical prostatectomy is not appropriate for metastatic prostate cancer.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and test results indicate prostate cancer with aggressive histologic features and metastasis. Androgen deprivation therapy is the most appropriate next step in management as it can improve symptoms and prolong survival in patients with metastatic prostate cancer. Active surveillance is not indicated in this case as the cancer is already aggressive and metastasized. Chemotherapy may be considered, but it is not the first-line treatment for metastatic prostate cancer. Radical prostatectomy is not indicated in this case as the cancer has already metastasized.
